user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskInstallDeleteHandler:
```c
int32 OS_TaskInstallDeleteHandler(osal_task_entry function_pointer)
{
    int32                      return_code;
    OS_object_token_t          token;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *task;
    osal_id_t                  task_id;

    task_id     = OS_TaskGetId_Impl();
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        task = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, token);

        /*
        ** Install the pointer
        */
        task->delete_hook_pointer = function_pointer;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskInstallDeleteHandler:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
osal_id_t OS_TaskGetId_Impl(void)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t self_record;

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    self_record.opaque_arg = pthread_getspecific(POSIX_GlobalVars.ThreadKey);

    return self_record.id;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
OS_task_internal_record_t OS_task_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct
{
    char            task_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    size_t          stack_size;
    osal_priority_t priority;
    osal_task_entry entry_function_pointer;
    osal_task_entry delete_hook_pointer;
    void *          entry_arg;
    osal_stackptr_t stack_pointer;
} OS_task_internal_record_t
...
typedef osal_task((*osal_task_entry)(void))
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments were identified as unreachable. Rationale:

- OS_TaskInstallDeleteHandler: The function performs a runtime call to OS_TaskGetId_Impl and uses the return value from OS_ObjectIdGetById to decide whether to execute the body. There are no constant-condition branches, no statements after an unconditional return, and no dead branches that the compiler could prove unreachable at compile time.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: The function contains early returns and conditional branches, but all branches are reachable depending on the results of OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, and OS_ObjectIdConvertToken. There is no code following an unconditional return or any branch conditioned on a compile-time constant that would make code unreachable.

- OS_TaskGetId_Impl and supporting macros/types: OS_TaskGetId_Impl returns a value derived from pthread_getspecific at runtime; this is not a compile-time constant. The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro and OS_ObjectIndexFromToken are evaluated at runtime using the token, so the indexed access is not statically unreachable.

- Other utility functions/macros (OS_ObjectIdRelease, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_task_table, structure definitions): These are normal definitions/uses with no statically unreachable code.

Given the provided code and definitions, there are no obvious unreachable-code fragments present that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1. If there are platform-specific invariants (for example, if certain functions are guaranteed to always fail or always succeed by design, or if LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS could be zero and cause other semantic issues), those would be behavioral constraints outside of static unreachable-code detection and would need separate review.
